text: Warm light shines from the study of the gracious Kingsley home. A man, silhouetted in the window, speaks with ardor
CHARLES KINGSLEY has just described his new venture to hi friends, including LORD ASCOT.
Charles, you have finally lost your senses.
This venture is impossible.
For some. Gentlemen, the only way to achieve the impossible is to believe it is possible.
That kind of thinking could ruin you.

I’m willing to take that chance. Imagine trading posts in Rangoon, Bangkok, Jakarta... He stops. His nine year-old daughter ALICE stands at the door in her nightgown, clearly frightened. He goes to her CHARLES KINGSLEY (CONT’D) The nightmare again? She nods. He takes her hand and turns to his guests. CHARLES KINGSLEY (CONT’D) I won’t be long. INT. YOUNG ALICE’S BEDROOM - LATER 3 He sits on her bed, listening with utmost seriousness.
I’m falling down a dark hole, then I see strange creatures...
What kind of creatures? (CONTINUED)
3 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 2.
Well, there’s a dodo bird, a rabbit in a waistcoat, a smiling cat...
I didn’t know cats could smile.
Neither did I. Oh, and there’s a blue caterpillar.
Blue caterpillar. Hmm.
Do you think I’ve gone round the bend? He feels her forehead as if for a fever.

I’m afraid so. You’re mad. Bonkers. off your head. But I’1l tell you a secret...all the best people are. She smiles and leans against him. CHARLES KINGSLEY (CONT’D) It’s only a dream, Alice. Nothing can harm you there. But if you get too frightened, you can always wake up. Like this. He pinches her. She screams and pinches him back.
A horse-drawn carriage careens down the road at a full gallop.

ALICE KINGSLEY is on the verge of womanhood, beautiful, b slightly off-kilter. She sees the world with different ey than other people her age. Presently, she’s tired and gru as her mother fusses with her wild mane of blonde hair.
Must we go? I doubt they’1ll notice if we never arrive. (CONTINUED)
10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 3.
They will notice. She re-ties her waist sash, feeling for her corset. HELEN KINGSLEY (CONT’D) Where’s your corset? She pulls back her dress to see bare legs. HELEN KINGSLEY (CONT’D) And no stockings!
I’m against them.
But you’re not properly dressed.
Who’s to say what is proper? What if it was agreed that “proper” was wearing a codfish on your head? Would you wear it?
Alice.
To me a corset is like a codfish.
Please. Not today. Frustrated, Alice looks out the window and mutters.

Father would have laughed. She sees the hurt on her mother’s face and instantly regr her words. ALICE (CONT’D) I’m sorry. I’m tired. I didn’t sleep well last night. Her mother pats her hand in a forgiving gesture.
Did you have bad dreams again? (CONTINUED)
10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 4.
Only one. It’s always the same ever since I can remember. Do you think that’s normal? Don’t most people have different dreams? Alice’s mother removes her own jewelry and puts it on her
I don’t know. There! You're beautiful. Now, can you manage a smile?

The garden party is in full swing. Everyone has turned ou in their summer finery. Guests play croquet on the great lawn. Skiffs drift lazily on a meandering river. Alice approaches LORD and LADY ASCOT with a fixed unnatur smile. Lord Ascot is a stately, aristocratic man. Lady Ascot is red-faced with annoyance.

At last! We thought you’d never arrive. Alice, Hamish is waiting to dance with you. Go! She pushes Alice off and turns on Helen. LADY ASCOT (CONT’D) You do realize it’s well past four! Now everything will have to be rushed through!
I am sorry. We...
Never mind! She rushes off.
Forgive my wife. She’s been planning this affair for the last twenty years.
If only Charles were here... (CONTINUED)
6 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 5.
My condolences, madame. I think of your husband often. He was truly a man of vision.
Thank you.
I hope you don’t think I have taken advantage of your misfortune.
Of course not. I’m pleased that you've purchased the company.
I was a fool for not investing in his mad venture when I had the chance. She smiles.
Charles thought so too.
Alice does a line dance with HAMISH who takes after his mother, refined and immaculate with aristocratic arroganc
Hamish, do you ever tire of the Quadrille?
On the contrary. I find it invigorating. He struts like a peacock. Alice laughs.
Do I amuse you?
No. I had a sudden vision of all the ladies in top hats and the men wearing bonnets. He doesn’t even crack a smile. (CONTINUED)
10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 6.

It would be best to keep your visions to yourself. When in doubt, remain silent. Alice’s smile fades. Without her father, she feels there’ no one like her in the whole world. They dance on. Alice sees a flock of geese overhead. Distracted, she bumps int the dancers in front of them.
Pardon us! Miss Kingsley is distracted today. (to Alice) Where is your head?
I was wondering what it would be like to fly.
Why would you waste your time thinking about such an impossible thing?
Why wouldn’t I? My father said he sometimes believed in six impossible things before breakfast. She laughs at the memory. Hamish looks pained. He sees hi mother nearby. She waves him on impatiently.
Meet me under the gazebo in precisely ten minutes. He goes off. Suddenly two giggling girls appear in front Alice. It’s the Chattaways.
We have a secret to tell you.
If you’re telling me, then it’s not much of a secret.
Perhaps we shouldn't.
We decided we should! (CONTINUED)
10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 7.
If we tell her, she won’t be surprised.
Will you be surprised?
Not if you tell me. But now you've brought it up, you have to.
No we don’t.
In fact, we won't.
I wonder if your mother knows that you two swim naked in the Havershim’s pond.
You wouldn't!
Oh, but I would. There’s your mother now. Alice starts to walk toward her. Fiona blurts out.
Hamish is going to ask for your hand! Alice stops dead. Her sister, MARGARET, suddenly pulls he away.
You’ve ruined the surprise! (to Alice) I could strangle them! Everyone went to so much effort to keep the secret.
Does everyone know?
It’s why they’ve all come. This is your engagement party. Hamish will ask you under the gazebo. When you say “yes”... (CONTINUED)
7 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 8.
But I don’t know if I want to marry him.
Who then? You won’t do better than a Lord. She looks at Hamish who blows his nose, studies the conte of his kerchief, then folds it and puts it in his pocket.

You'll soon be twenty, Alice. That pretty face won’t last forever. You don’t want to end up like Aunt Imogene. They look at their middle-aged AUNT IMOGENE with over-rou cheeks and a yellowing white dress that’s too young for h
And you don’t want to be a burden on mother, do you?
No.
So you will marry Hamish. You will be as happy as I am with Lowell and your life will be perfect. It’s already decided. Lady Ascot's face suddenly looms in hers.
Alice dear, shall we take a leisurely stroll through the garden? Just you and me? She jerks her away quickly.
Lady Ascot steers her through the gardens at a fast clip.
Do you know what I’ve always dreaded?
The decline of the aristocracy? (CONTINUED)

Ugly grandchildren. But you’re so lovely. You’re bound to produce little... (she gasps) Imbeciles! The gardeners planted white roses when I specifically asked for red!
You could always paint the roses red. Lady Ascot looks at her strangely.
What an odd thing to say. Come along. She hurries her along the path. Alice hears a jingling so
You should know that my son has extremely delicate digestion... Alice sees SOMETHING LARGE AND WHITE dart past.
Did you see that?
See what?
It was a rabbit, I think.

Nasty things. I do enjoy setting the dogs on them. Don’t dawdle. She rushes Alice toward the gazebo. Alice looks for the rabbit. LADY ASCOT (CONT’D) If you serve Hamish the wrong foods, he could get a blockage. And there it is, a LARGE WHITE RABBIT in a waistcoat, standing on its hind legs and staring directly at Alice. blinks. The White Rabbit darts behind a tree.

Aunt Imogene! I think I’m going mad. I keep seeing a rabbit in a waistcoat.
How very strange. What kind of waistcoat?
Brocade, I think. What does it matter? It’s a rabbit in a waistcoat!

You have a fiance? The White Rabbit darts by. ALICE (CONT’D) There! Did you see it?
He’s a prince. But, alas he cannot marry me unless he renounces his throne. Isn’t it tragic?
Very. (CONTINUED)

She backs away and runs into her sister’s husband, LOWELL kissing a strange woman. The woman runs off.
Lowell?
Alice. We were...Hattie is an old friend.
I can see you’re very close. Lowell is bright red and highly flustered.
You won’t mention this to your sister, will you?
I don’t know. I’m confused. I need time to think.
Think of Margaret. She would never trust me again. You don’t want to ruin her marriage, do you?
Me? I’m not the one... Suddenly Hamish is there, annoyed.

He pulls her under the gazebo. The shadows of the pillars fall on her like prison bars. She glances at a string quartet discreetly positioned in the shadows... bows pois Hamish drops to his knee. Alice notices an artist immortalizing the moment.
Alice Kingsley...
Hamish. (CONTINUED)

You have a caterpillar on your shoulder. He frantically brushes at his shoulder. ALICE (CONT’D) Don’t hurt it. Alice lets the CATERPILLAR crawl onto her finger, then pl it gently onto a tree branch.
You’1l want to wash that finger. He sees his mother motioning to him from below. Everyone watching. He blurts out.
Alice Kingsley, will you be my wife? The question hangs in the air. Unsure of herself, unsure her future, unsure of her own sanity in that moment, Alic stammers.

I...IT....e well, everyone expects me to...and you’re a Lord...and my face won’t last...and I don’t want to end up like...but this is happening so quickly...I think...I...I... She looks at a label. “DRINK ME”. She sniffs the contents recoils, then shrugs. ALICE (CONT’D) It’s only a dream. She takes a drink, shudders, gags and coughs from the tas In a moment, she notices that the table is getting larger ALICE (CONT’D) That’s curious. Alice SHRINKS to two feet high.

The doors loom above her. She takes a step and trips on h now-oversized clothes. Dragging them behind, she tries to open the door. But it’s still locked. She groans as she realizes what she’s done. She goes back to the glass tabl where she can see the gold key sitting on top.
We hear VOICES as they watch Alice through a keyhole.
You'd think she would remember this from the first time.
You've brought the wrong Alice.

Alice attempts to climb the table leg, but gets tangled i her too-big clothes and slides off. She notices a little under the table. She looks around for the unseen person.
If this is some sort of prank, I am not amused! She opens the box. It’s a cake with “EAT ME” written out ornate icing. She considers, looks up at the key high abo on the table. (CONTINUED)

She takes a tiny taste of the cake. She takes another bit WHOOSH! She shoots upward rapidly. Her clothes fit again, but she keeps growing. Buttons pop, seams are strained an her skirt gets shorter. The ceiling gets closer...her hea grazes it! She stops. Relieved, she bends down and picks the gold key. Crouching, she goes to the little door and fits the key in the lock.

She laughs at herself and goes back to the table. She pic up the little bottle and takes another swallow, shivers a the taste, then shrinks again to two feet high. Dragging too-big clothes, she runs to the door, puts the key in th lock, opens it and steps through. EXT. A GARDEN IN UNDERLAND — DAY 17 She enters a fantastical world. Underland is bizarre, illogical, often dangerous, absurd, and strangely beautif The garden is brown and tangled, its statues broken and overgrown. The mossy fountain is silent. Alice hears a bellow/sneezing sound as a GREEN PIG dashes past. The TAL FLOWERS have gaunt, haunted HUMAN FACES. SHABBY, THIN BIR walk on stalk legs.
